intro.p:
This content
book is divided into three sections
chapters . An overview of the physiology and behaviour of birds is given in the INTRODUCTION; the section
chapter on ................................. on orders, families, and individual species of bird.

section.head: Introduction
section.p:
This opening section
chapter provides information on the physical characteristics of birds, focusing on the aspects of their physiology that differentiate birds from the rest ............ are also discussed in the closing pages of this chapter.

caption.head: Anatomy and physiology
caption.p:
These sections
pages include detailed descriptions of the physical characteristics of birds and the ways in which these have evolved to serve the needs of different types of bird in a variety of environments.

intro.p: some groups of animals are easily confused, but there are no such problems with birds. They are the only animals that have feathers, and ............................. spend years on the wing before finally landing to breed.

section.head: Skeleton and muscles
section.p: All birds have evolved from the same distant ancestors and, as a result, they share the same underlying body plan. Their skeletons contain fewer bones than .....................which averages 40–42ºC (104–107ºF).

caption.head: Internal organs
caption.p: Birds have similar body systems to mammals, but their organs differ. Most have a crop and a gizzard in the digestive system, and a single opening called the cloaca for excretion and reproduction.

intro.p: Classification is the science of identifying and categorizing living things and, among ornithologists, few topics generate as much debate. This is because ..................... such as internal processes or behaviour. But in recent years, the advances in molecular biology have allowed ornithologists to go to the very source of bird evolution, by studying DNA itself.

Found only in Central and South America, tinamous superficially resemble gamebirds
(see p.107) , with small heads, plump bodies, and short legs. However, although they can fly, their skeletons show .........................., fast-beating wings but, if threatened, their first instinct is to run away.

dataset.data: Primary and secondary rainforest, with an open forest floor

section.p: The haunting song of the Great Tinamou, consisting of up to seven tremulous, whistled notes, is one of the most evocative of Neotropical bird sounds, cutting through the forest before dawn and around dusk. It is a large, brown bird that wanders on the forest floor, eating insects, frogs, berries, fruit, and seeds.

intro.p: with humpbacked bodies and long, decurved bills, kiwis are unmistakable, and recognized the world over as New Zealand’s national bird.................... earthworms and other small animals.

feature.head: Conservation
feature.p:
Like many of New Zealand’s native birds, kiwis have been decimated by introduced mammals. A nationwide conservation programme is aimed at reversing a decline of upto 5 per cent a year. Conservation measures include setting traps
(right) for rats and stoats, which prey on kiwi chicks.

feature.head: Stewart Island
feature.p: Brown Kiwis are relatively common on New Zealand’s Stewart Island. The island is rich in other bird species including the Yellow-eyed Penguin (the world’s rarest penguin). Predator-free islands around Stewart are home to some of the world’s rarest birds, such as the Kakapo.

gloss_entry.description: A fully developed, mature bird that is able to breed. It is in its final plumage, which no longer changes pattern with age. See also immature.
A bird’s wing is based on an aerodynamic shape called an aerofoil. It is curved outwards along the entire upper surface, to produce an upward force known as lift.
